content:
• Wednesday, February 17, 2016
  • ADTM

    Adaptive Medias hires Roth to examine buyout bid

    • Adaptive Medias (OTCPK:ADTM +4.1%) said today it's hired Roth Capital Partners to serve as a strategic adviser "in particular related to an unsolicited offer recently received by the company."
    • Shares had skyrocketed earlier this month after the company confirmed it had a $35M acquisition proposal (a 1000% premium at the time) from privately held AdSupply.
    • Roth will no doubt look over that proposal as well as take on "an effort to identify other prospective buyers or strategic partners."
    • Previously: Adaptive Medias sets three-year contract with CEO Strong (Feb. 05 2016)
    • Previously: Adaptive Medias jumps on buyout offer at 900% premium (Feb. 01 2016)
    • Previously: Adaptive Medias receives buyout bid at 1000% premium (Jan. 29 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:11 PM
  • PSXP

    Phillips 66 Partners paying $236M for controlling stake in fractionator, storage

    • Phillips 66 Partners (NYSE:PSXP) says it's acquired a quarter-share (controlling) interest in newly constructed Sweeny Fractionator One and Clemens Caverns storage facility.
    • It'll pay total consideration of $236M for the 25% of Phillips 66 Sweeny Frac LLC, which owns the two new facilities. That's made up of assuming $212M in notes payable to Phillips 66 (PSX +3%), and $24M in newly issued PSXP units.
    • The company says the deal should be immediately accretive to unitholders. The Sweeny unit is a 100,000 bpd NGL fractionator in Old Ocean, Texas; Clemens Caverns has storage capacity of about 7.5M barrels of Y-grade NGL with future expansion possibilities.
    • The acquisition is set to close in early March.
    • After hours: PSX +0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:05 PM | 7 Comments
  • TELNY

    Telenor taking VimpelCom news 'very seriously'; VIP +12.5%

    • Telenor (OTCPK:TELNY +4.7%) -- one of a few companies ensnared in the Uzbekistan corruption scandal -- says it is closely following news of VimpelCom's (VIP +12.5%) reported settlement in the deal, and acknowledgment that it broke U.S. and Dutch laws.
    • "Corruption is unacceptable, and Telenor takes it very seriously that VimpelCom now seems to acknowledge certain violations of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and relevant Dutch Laws," the Norwegian telecom said in a statement.
    • Telenor had cut ties via a consulting arrangement with its ex-CEO, Jon Fredrik Baksaas, and suspended its CFO and general counsel as the scandal developed.
    • It had owned a third of VimpelCom before saying in October that it would divest the multibillion-dollar stake and take a related $900M impairment.
    • Previously: VimpelCom up 6.2% on word it's settling Uzbek probes (Feb. 17 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:52 PM
  • FOX

    CBS pulls rare broadcast ratings sweep of top 10 shows

    • Only a competing Republican debate could have messed this up for CBS -- so luckily, it was the network who broadcast this week's.
    • The network swept the top 10 shows in the ratings, with the exception of The Walking Dead on AMC, which finished third with 13.7M viewers. But the other nine of the top 10 programs were all on the Tiffany Network.
    • CBS (CBS +3.7%) says that's the first time in a decade that one of the major broadcasters has pulled that off.
    • Saturday's GOP debate was the No. 4 program, with 13.44M viewers. Topping the list were NCIS, with 16.94M, and The Big Bang Theory, with 16.25M. A pair of NCIS spinoffs, along with Scorpion, Blue Bloods, Madam Secretary and 60 Minutes filled out the rest of the list.
    • TNT (TWX +2.2%) topped cable networks, averaging 2.37M prime-time viewers, ahead of Fox News' (FOX +3.3%, FOXA +3.4%) 2.33M and AMC's (AMCX +3.2%) 1.96M. In news, NBC Nightly News (CMCSA +0.4%) led with 9.4M viewers.
    • In the season so far, CBS is unsurprisingly tops in prime-time viewers overall with an average 11.74M.
    • Previously: 'Walking Dead' midseason premiere ratings down, but still big (Feb. 17 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:30 PM | 2 Comments
  • TECD

    TECD, SNX, ARW tick higher after Chinese firm strikes deal to buy Ingram

    • Tech Data (NASDAQ:TECD) is up 3.7% after hours to $69.44 following news fellow IT product distributor Ingram Micro is being acquired by Chinese logistics firm Tianjin Tianhai for $6B, or a 31% premium to Ingram's Wednesday close.
    • Synnex (NYSE:SNX) is up 1.1% to $90.00. Arrow Electronics (NYSE:ARW) is up 0.9% to $56.65.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:07 PM
  • CSLT

    Castlight lower after Q4 beat, cautious Q1 guidance

    • Though Castlight Health (NYSE:CSLT) slightly beat Q4 estimates, the company is guiding for Q1 revenue of $22M-$22.3M and EPS of -$0.15 to -$0.16 vs. a consensus of $22.3M and -$0.14.
    • Full-year guidance is in-line: Revenue of $99M-$102M (+31%-35% Y/Y) and EPS of -$0.47 to -$0.51 vs. a consensus of $100.8M and -$0.50.
    • Castlight added nine Fortune 500 clients for its cloud healthcare software platform over the whole of 2015. GAAP operating expenses rose 11% Y/Y in Q4 to $30.8M, a slower pace of growth than in recent quarters. Castlight ended 2015 with $133.8M in cash/investments and no debt.
    • CSLT -5.4% after hours to $3.15. The post-IPO low (set last Thursday) is $2.54.
    • Castlight's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 7:01 PM
  • TWX

    'Walking Dead' midseason premiere ratings down, but still big

    • The Walking Dead, AMC Networks' (AMCX +3.2%) monster hit and flagship TV show, returned with a midseason premiere Sunday that pulled off that rare feat of disappointing despite huge numbers.
    • The show drew a 6.8 rating among adults 18-49 (down 15% from comparable premiere last year), and 13.7M viewers (down 12%) in live-plus-same-day estimates -- not up to the level of past episodes, but still outdrawing broadcast-network hits.
    • A holiday weekend and a Valentine's Day premiere couldn't have helped, not to mention the NBA All-Star Game (7.61M viewers on TNT and TBS (NYSE:TWX)) and a basic-cable premiere of Disney's Frozen. (3.9M viewers). AMC is looking forward to some help from delayed-viewing ratings.
    • But the show's streak of growing ratings every half-season peaked a year ago when the end of season five dipped below the first half.
    • The season premiere of follow-up show Talking Dead drew a 3.1 rating in the demo and 6.44M viewers overall, better than all eight fall episodes.
    • Previously: Piper Jaffray sees growth ahead, reiterates Overweight on AMC Networks (Jan. 07 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:01 PM | 4 Comments
  • CF

    CF Industries posts Q4 earnings miss as fertilizer prices weaken

    • CF Industries (NYSE:CF) -4.4% AH after reporting lower than expected Q4 earnings, hurt by fertilizer prices that have plunged amid soft grain prices and global overproduction.
    • CF says its Q4 average selling price for ammonia fell ~18% Y/Y to $458/ton, while the price of urea ammonium nitrate fell 12.5% to $230/ton; meanwhile, CF's total operating costs and expenses jumped 50% to $88.3M.
    • CF says it expects 2016 corn planting to cover ~90.5M acres, a 2.5M acre increase from 2015.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:58 PM | 3 Comments
  • ARRS

    Arris tumbles after mixed Q4 results, soft Q1 guidance

    • In addition to missing Q4 revenue estimates (while beating on EPS), Arris (NASDAQ:ARRS) is guiding for Q1 revenue of $1.56B-$1.61B and EPS of $0.37-$0.42, below a consensus of $1.68B and $0.58. The guidance accounts for the Pace acquisition, which closed on Jan. 4.
    • Along with its numbers, Arris has announced a $300M buyback. It replaces prior authorizations, and is good for repurchasing 9% of shares at current levels.
    • Q4 details: Order backlog stood at $715.8M as of the end of Q4 (before the Pace deal closed), up 28% Y/Y. Q4 book-to-bill was 1.14. GAAP operating expenses rose 5% to $305.8M. Arris ended 2015 with $879M in cash and over $1.5B in debt.
    • ARRS -9.2% after hours to $21.70.
    • Arris' Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:38 PM
  • MAR

    Marriott, Starwood set March 28 meeting for merger votes

    • Marriott (MAR +2.5%) and Starwood (HOT +2.7%) have set shareholder meetings to approve the transactions related to Marriott's $12.2B buyout bid.
    • The two companies will meet separately on March 28 at 10 a.m. ET to consider the deal. A joint proxy statement will be mailed out starting Friday.
    • A number of approvals (and Starwood's divestiture of its vacation ownership business) lie ahead for the transaction, which they expect to close in mid-2016.
    • Marriott will hold off buybacks from today until the vote to comply with securities laws.
    • The two agreed on a $12.2B deal in November to create the world's largest hotel company.
    • After hours: MAR -2.5%; HOT +0.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:37 PM | 1 Comment
  • MRO

    Marathon Oil moves higher after posting Q4 beat, cutting capex by 50%-plus

    • Marathon Oil (NYSE:MRO) +3.5% AH after reporting a Q4 loss in-line with expectations and better than expected revenue of $1.48B.
    • MRO says Q4 net production averaged 432K boe/day, roughly flat Q/Q and up 8% Y/Y, but the cost of production fell 28% Y/Y.
    • MRO sees total FY 2016 production coming in 6%-8% lower than 2015, amid plans to cap spending on capital projects at $1.4B compared with $3B spent in 2015, which was ~$500M below the outlay the company originally planned.
    • MRO says it expects to sell $750M-$1B in assets this year, compared with its previous projection of non-core asset sales of at least $500M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:29 PM | 4 Comments
  • BRCD

    Brocade gains after FQ1 beat, in-line FQ2 guidance

    • Brocade (NASDAQ:BRCD) is up 5.9% after hours to $9.02 after beating FQ1 estimates and issuing in-line FQ2 guidance in its earnings presentation (.pdf) - revenue of $542M-$562M and EPS of $0.22-$0.24 vs. a consensus of $550.9M and $0.22. Adjusted free cash flow is expected to total $100M-$120M, after totaling $96M (above guidance of $30M-$50M) in FQ1.
    • Top-line performance: SAN product revenue fell 2% Y/Y to $347M, but was above Brocade's guidance. Weak demand for embedded and fixed-configuration Fibre Channel switches (hurt by soft enterprise storage demand) offset continued director switch strength.

      IP networking product revenue rose 1% to $134M (below the midpoint of Brocade's guidance), with strong enterprise demand and a 19% increase in switch sales offsetting weak service provider/federal demand and a 25% drop in router sales. Global services revenue rose 3% to $93M.
    • Top-line guidance: Due to seasonality, SAN product revenue is expected to drop 7%-10.5% Q/Q, and IP networking revenue rise 3%-9%. Global services is expected to be flat.
    • Financials: Boosting EPS: $144.5M was spent on buybacks. Also helping: Non-GAAP gross margin rose 90 bps Q/Q and 40 bps Y/Y to 68.8%. GAAP operating expenses rose 7% Y/Y to $267.8M. Brocade ended FQ1 with $1.39B in cash and $798M in debt.
    • Brocade's FQ1 results, earnings release (.pdf)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:28 PM
  • GDDY

    GoDaddy lower in spite of Q4 beat, in-line sales guidance

    • GoDaddy (NYSE:GDDY) is down 3.8% after hours to $28.00 in spite of beating Q4 estimates and issuing in-line sales guidance: Q1 revenue of $428M-$432M and 2016 revenue of $1.82B-$1.845B vs. consensus estimates of $431.1M and $1.83B. Adjusted EBITDA is expected to rise to $400M-$410M in 2016 from 2015's $337.4M (+24.3% Y/Y).
    • Top-line performance: Bookings rose 13.3% Y/Y in Q4 to $464M, topping revenue of $425.4M (+14.4%). Domains revenue +9.5% to $218.1M; hosting/presence +12.7% to $155.5M; business applications +50.1% to $51.8M.
    • Customers rose 8.7% Y/Y to 13.8M. ARPU rose 6.3% to $121. GoDaddy says it now has 62M domains under management (over 20% of all domains), and operates in 53 markets and 26 languages following its recent Asian launch.
    • Financials: GAAP costs/expenses rose 10% Y/Y in Q4 to $412.6M. Unlevered free cash flow totaled $52.3M, and rose 53.7% Y/Y over the whole of 2015 to $294.1M. GoDaddy ended 2015 with $352.5M in cash and $1.04B in long-term debt.
    • GoDaddy's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:00 PM | 4 Comments
  • GOLD

    Barrick Gold eyes another $2B in debt reduction this year

    • Barrick Gold (ABX) -2.4% AH despite reporting better than expected Q4 earnings and revenues, and saying it plans to reduce net debt by at least $2B this year through the sale of additional non-core assets and creation of new joint ventures and partnerships.
    • ABX's unadjusted Q4 loss totaled $2.62B, including $3.1B in impairments mainly related to an adjustment in the company’s gold price assumptions; ABX had warned last month that it would record the charges.
    • In FY 2015, ABX says it recorded positive free cash flow for the first time in four years despite lower gold prices, generating $471M in free cash flow, including $387M in Q4; the company's total debt was reduced by $3.1B, or 24%.
    • ABX guides 2016 production of 5M-5.5M oz. of gold at all-in sustaining costs of $775-$825/oz. and 2017 production of 5M-5.5M oz. at all-in sustaining costs of $740-$790/oz.
    • ABX says its "over-arching objective is to generate, and ideally grow, free cash flow in any foreseeable gold price environment," and will seek to achieve all-in sustaining costs below $700/oz. by 2019.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:58 PM | 10 Comments

  • NEM

    Newmont Mining slides on Q4 earnings miss

    • Newmont Mining (NYSE:NEM) -2.9% AH after reporting weaker than expected Q4 earnings of $0.04/share, down from $0.17 in the year-ago quarter, on 10% lower revenues of $1.82B, hurt by lower metal prices and delayed exports from Indonesia.
    • NEM says its average realized gold and copper price fell to a respective $1,084/oz. and $1.86/lb. in Q4, compared with $1,194/oz. and $2.55/lb. a year earlier.
    • NEM says Q4 gold production was flat at 1.3M oz., while copper production reached 39K metric tons vs. 29K a year earlier due to a higher grade ore at the Batu Hijau location.
    • NEM guides gold production of 4.8M-5.3M oz. in 2016 and 5.2M-5.7M oz. in 2017, before stabilizing at 4.5M-5M oz. through 2020 at all-in sustained costs below $1K/oz.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM | 3 Comments
  • IPAS

    IPass to cut 30% of workforce; misses on profits, revenues

    • Wi-Fi provider iPass (IPAS +2.9%) announced job cuts to 30% of its workforce, and missed consensus on top and bottom lines, in its Q4 results.
    • The cuts will have an impact on about 60 employees, mainly eliminating positions in engineering and network operations, "including a significant rightsizing of the India team." It'll take a $1M charge to implement its plan in Q1 and expects annualized savings of about $4M. "IPass is truly a startup again," CEO Gary Griffiths said on the company's earnings call.
    • Legacy revenue headwinds have been mitigated, it says, with legacy revenue falling $8.3M with an annualized run rate of $2.8M heading into 2016.
    • It's guiding to Q1 revenues of $14.7M-$15.5M, light of an expected $17.3M, and for adjusted EBITDA of -$2.5M to -$1.5M (vs. an expected $0.1M). For the first time, it's providing full-year guidance (and dropping quarterly forecasts): It's foreseeing $63M-$68M in revenues (below an expected $77.2M) and EBITDA of -$1M to $1M (light of an expected $4.2M).
    • Conference call link
     
     
     
     
    | 5:29 PM
  • ELNK

    EarthLink gains 2.5% as Q4 revenue beats expectations

    • EarthLink (ELNK +2.2%) is up another 2.5% after hours after posting revenue that beat expectations despite shrinking by 8.5% from last year.
    • Net loss shrunk to $12.3M from the prior-year loss of $22.5M. For the full year, net loss of $43.2M was down from 2014's net loss of $72.8M.
    • Revenue by segment: Business Services, $206.9M (down 8.3%); Consumer Services, $53.3M (down 9.4%). Of Business Services: Enterprise/Mid-Market revenues were $106.2M; Small Business, $66.5M; and Carrier/Transport, $34.3M.
    • Unlevered free cash flow was $26.8M, up from the prior year's $24.6M. The company ended 2015 with $91.3M in cash.
    • David Koretz and Wayne Wisehart are retiring from the aboard prior to the annual meeting in April.
    • Conference call to come tomorrow at 8:30 a.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:17 PM
  • MRVL

    Marvell up 4.8% after resuming trading

    • Marvell (NASDAQ:MRVL) has risen to $9.75 in after hours trading following news the company is settling Carnegie Mellon's infringement suit through an aggregate payment of $750M (with no royalties).
    • For reference, Marvell closed today with a $4.8B market cap.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM
  • BCE

    Canada to broadcasters: Don't cut back on news

    • Canadian broadcasters have cut jobs and programming in recent months amid hot digital competition, but Canada's regulator has sent a warning not to cut back on news content.
    • The news comes ahead of key license renewals coming next year. "There were decisions made recently that were completely valid because there were no conditions of license," Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission Chairman Jean-Pierre Blais says. "The good thing about licensing renewals is that we have an opportunity to have a second look."
    • BCE and Rogers Communications have each gone through cutbacks of hundreds of jobs. But Blais said companies need to serve an audience eager for quality journalism, and that the regulator would issue new rules for local TV news in June, ahead of beginning hearings on license renewals.
    • Canadian TV: BCE flat, RCI +2.2%, SJR +1.6%, TU +0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 12 Comments
  • NVDA

    Nvidia gains after FQ4 beat, strong FQ1 guidance; gaming GPUs, Tegra stand out

    • In addition to soundly beating FQ4 estimates, Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) is guiding for FQ1 revenue of $1.26B (+/- 2%), above a $1.23B consensus.
    • Top-line performance: As was the case in FQ3, strong gaming GPU demand (in spite of a weak PC market) was a major tailwind: Total GPU revenue rose 10% Y/Y to $1.18B, with gaming GPU revenue rising 21%. Quadro (workstation GPU) revenue rose 7% to $203M, and Tesla/GRID (HPC server/cloud) GPU revenue rose 10% to $97M.

      Tegra app processor revenue rose 40% to $157M, fueled by a 68% increase in automotive revenue to $93M (the result of both infotainment module Tegra sales and R&D contracts). The Intel deal once more produced licensing revenue of $66M.
    • Financials: Non-GAAP gross margin was 57.2%, +70 bps Q/Q and +100 bps Y/Y, and above a guidance midpoint of 57%. FQ1 GM guidance is at 57.5% (+/- 50 bps). Operating expenses rose 6% Y/Y to $445M (compares with 12% revenue growth). 4.3M shares were repurchased through an accelerated buyback. Nvidia ended FQ4 with $5.04B in cash and $1.41B in convertible debt.
    • NVDA +5.6% after hours to $29.20.
    • Nvidia's FQ4 results, earnings release, CFO commentary (.pdf)

    Chinese firm buying Ingram Micro for $6B ($38.90/share)

  • JACK

    Sales come in soft at Jack in the Box

    • Shares of Jack in the Box (NASDAQ:JACK) are halted after the restaurant chain's sales came in short of expectations.
    • The Jack in the Box chain showed a 1.4% gain in system-wide comps, while system-wide comp sales at Qdoba were up 1.8%. McDonald's All-Day Breakfast may have factored into the Jack comp, while any lift from Chipotle's issues for Qdoba appears to have been slight.
    • Consolidated restaurant operating margin improved 20 bps to 19.5% as lower food and packaging costs played in.
    • The outlook for FY16 EPS guidance was lowered as the company now sees only a 1% to 2% gain in same-store sales for the year.
    • Previously: Jack In The Box misses by $0.10, misses on revenue (Feb. 17)

  • ANAD

    Anadigics deems $0.78/share Chinese offer superior to II-VI deal

    • Following a fresh set of deal term revisions, Anadigics (NASDAQ:ANAD) states a $0.78/share buyout offer delivered yesterday from a Chinese suitor referred to as "Party B" is superior to the company's $0.66/share deal to sell to II-VI (NASDAQ:IIVI). II-VI has three business days to respond.
    • Anadigics: "To protect the Company and its stockholders in the event the closing of the proposed merger transaction with Party B does not close in a timely manner or at all as a result of the review process to be conducted by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, the February 16, 2016 Party B Proposed Merger Agreement provides, among other things, that, under certain circumstances identified therein, Party B will make a loan available to the Company and/or pay to the Company a reverse termination fee."
    • ANAD +2.7% after hours to $0.70.

    NetApp posts mixed results, issues soft guidance; shares drop

    • Revenue of $1.39B (-10.3% Y/Y) misses by $60M.

  • CYBR

    CyberArk, GoDaddy close up strongly following analyst defenses

    • Privilged account security software firm CyberArk (CYBR +5.3%) and SMB Web hosting/domain registration provider GoDaddy (GDDY +7.4%) outperformed on a day the Nasdaq rose 2.2%. Upbeat analyst notes (from JPMorgan and Deutsche, respectively) could be helping.
    • JPMorgan's Sterling Auty (Overweight rating, $48 target) argues CyberArk's post-earnings selloff (follows a Q4 beat and mixed 2016 guidance) is excessive. "We think investors should take a step back and look at CYBR in context of the broader security stocks so they can see that CYBR generated the fastest year-over-year revenue growth in the December quarter."
    • He adds CyberArk has a track record of under-promising and over-delivering, and notes 63% of respondents for a security survey mentioned they plan "privilege security project in 2016."
    • Deutsche's Ross Sandler (Buy rating, $34 target) is upbeat about GoDaddy ahead of Wednesday afternoon's Q4 report. "GDDY is the best-positioned company in the website presence sector given its dominant competitive position and still has plenty of opportunity to upsell incremental higher ARPU products to its 14m customer base."
    • He expects GoDaddy to deliver 14% 2016 revenue growth, with customers rising 8% and ARPU 5%. Meanwhile, smart ad spending and a mix shift towards higher-margin Web presence and business apps are seen potentially fueling margin growth.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:01 PM
  • GILD

    Gilead down on potential erosion of Harvoni sales from Regulus's RG-101

    • It's rare, but Gilead Sciences (GILD -2%) failed to participate in biotech's up day. The reason for the lack of buying appears to be the earlier news of positive Phase 2 data from Regulus Therapeutics (RGLS +18.5%) regarding HCV candidate RG-101. Preliminary results showed a 97% cure rate from a four-week regimen of RG-101 and certain retrovirals, including Harvoni. It seems like a long shot, but investors apparently perceive a risk that the regimen will gain traction and Harvoni sales could (theoretically) be cut in half.
    • Previously: Regulus Therapeutics' HCV candidate shows 97% cure rate after eight weeks in mid-stage study; shares up 43% premarket (Feb. 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 222 Comments
  • ENLC

    EnLink Midstream, EnLink Partners sink following Q4 results

    • EnLink Midstream (ENLC -19.4%) and EnLink Midstream Partners (ENLK -6.8%) are sharply lower near the close after both companies reported big Q4 losses (I, II).

    Inovio's Zika vaccine candidate shows robust immune response in preclinical testing; shares up 4%

    • Micro cap Inovio Pharmaceuticals (INO +4%) is up in early trading on increased volume in response to its announcement of positive preclinical data for its Zika virus vaccine candidate. In the study, DNA constructs, synthetically generated with the company's SynCon vaccine technology, targeting multiple Zika virus antigens and administered using its CELLECTRA electroporation delivery technology induced robust and durable immune responses. Phase 1 testing is expected to commence before year end.
    • Investors seeking to profit from a Zika-stoked up move need to be patient. Regulatory clearance for a vaccine, even with accelerated review, is probably two years away. Drugs to treat infection are further away still.
    • Intrexon (XON +6.4%) has seen some recent bullish action (shares doubled from mid-January to early February) in apparent anticipation of the revenue potential of its genetically modified sterile male mosquitoes, OX513A, that produced a 95% reduction in the Aedes aegypti population, the type of mosquito that transmits Zika and Dengue, in a small study in northeast Brazil. Here, again, sobriety is key. The beneficial effects are only temporary (unless the sterile guys are repeatedly released over a wide area, a tall order since mosquitoes only travel ~200 yards so covering a large area would require substantial human and physical resources). Intrexon's pricing leverage will also be constrained because irradiated sterile mosquitoes perform just as effectively and they will be available free-of-charge. Both techniques have similar cost structures, about $400/1M mosquitoes.
